title: The Plagues of Livestock, Boils, and Hail
shortSummary: Exodus chapter 9 details God's continued judgment on Egypt through devastating plagues, including the death of livestock, painful boils, and a fierce hailstorm. Despite these clear displays of divine power and mercy toward Israel, Pharaoh's heart remains hardened, underscoring the conflict between God's sovereignty and human stubbornness.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: God's chosen leader who confronts Pharaoh and delivers God's commands and warnings throughout the plagues.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Moses' brother and spokesperson who assists in performing signs before Pharaoh.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The king of Egypt who repeatedly refuses to obey God's command to release the Israelites, hardening his heart against God.

definitions.definition: A deadly disease affecting cattle and livestock, used here to describe the plague that kills Egypt’s animals.
Painful skin sores or eruptions caused by the plague of ashes, symbolizing God’s judgment on both man and beast.
Frozen precipitation used as a severe natural judgment from God, accompanied by thunder and fire in this chapter.
A biblical phrase indicating Pharaoh’s stubborn refusal to submit to God’s will, despite clear evidence of His power.

outline.heading: The Plague on the Livestock
outline.description: God warns Pharaoh through Moses that if he refuses to release Israel, a deadly plague will strike Egypt’s livestock but spare Israel’s animals, demonstrating God’s protective power over His people.

outline.heading: The Plague of Boils
outline.description: Moses and Aaron cause painful boils to break out on Egyptians and their animals by sprinkling furnace ashes, further showing God’s judgment and Pharaoh’s increasing resistance.

outline.heading: God’s Declaration of Judgment and Purpose
outline.description: God explains to Moses that the plagues serve to reveal His unmatched power and to make His name known throughout the earth, while also highlighting Pharaoh’s prideful opposition.

outline.heading: The Plague of Hail
outline.description: God sends a devastating hailstorm with thunder and fire, destroying crops and livestock in Egypt except in Goshen, where the Israelites live, emphasizing God’s mercy toward His people.

outline.heading: Pharaoh’s Temporary Repentance and Continued Hardness
outline.description: Pharaoh admits his sin and requests the hail to stop, but after the storm ceases, he hardens his heart again, refusing to release the Israelites as God had predicted.

application: Trust in God’s sovereign protection and provision, as He distinguishes His people even in judgment.
Recognize the seriousness of resisting God’s commands and the danger of hardening one’s heart against Him.
Respond to God’s warnings with repentance and obedience rather than stubbornness and delay.
Pray for a soft heart that is willing to submit to God’s authority and acknowledge His power.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD shall sever between the cattle of Israel and the cattle of Egypt: and there shall nothing die of all that is the children's of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's protective distinction between His people and Egypt, demonstrating His faithfulness and power.

keyVerses.text: For I will at this time send all my plagues upon thine heart, and upon thy servants, and upon thy people; that thou mayest know that there is none like me in all the earth.
keyVerses.significance: God declares His unique sovereignty and authority over all creation, emphasizing the purpose behind the plagues.

keyVerses.text: Only in the land of Goshen, where the children of Israel were, was there no hail.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores God's mercy and protection over His covenant people amid judgment on Egypt.

keyVerses.text: And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened, neither would he let the children of Israel go; as the LORD had spoken by Moses.
keyVerses.significance: Pharaoh's persistent hardness of heart fulfills God's word and sets the stage for further judgment.
